title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
I used ChatGPT as my main GenAI tool.
I chose ChatGPT because it is easy to use and can help with: - Writing content
- Formatting in Markdown
- Understanding Quarto syntax
- Debugging errors



ChatGPT helped me: - Generate page content when I was unsure how to start
- Format my text using Markdown
- Structure my website pages logically
For example, it helped me write the project page and the data visualization explanation in a clear way.




Saves time

Helps organize ideas

Reduces frustration when stuck




Sometimes the generated text is too general, so I still had to: - Edit the content
- Add my own experience
- Make it more personal



I think GenAI will be very useful for: - Writing reports
- Debugging code
- Learning new topics
- Preparing presentations
It is a powerful assistant, but it still needs human judgment.

title: Final Year Project (FYP)
text:
One of my past project focused on machine learning-based phishing email detection, aiming to automatically classify emails as phishing or non-phishing.



Steps I took: 1. Data Collection and Preprocessing
- Collected emails and extracted numerical/categorical features
2. Feature Analysis and Selection
- Identified top features using visualizations like the bar chart
3. Model Development
- Trained classifiers like Random Forest and XGBoost
4. Evaluation and Deployment
- Evaluated with accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score
- Integrated top model into a prototype email filter




Achieved high classification accuracy without overfitting

Produced explainable results using feature importance visualizations

Maintained a reproducible workflow for data analysis and model training





Combining exploratory analysis, visualization, and machine learning is powerful

Clear presentation of results improves stakeholder understanding

Reflection on each step helps me improve future projects

title: Data Visualization
text:
I worked on a phishing email detection project to classify emails as phishing or non-phishing based on content and metadata.
The goal of this page is to explain how I analyzed features and visualized them.



I created a bar chart showing the top 5 numerical features for predicting phishing emails:



Top 5 Features for Phishing Email Detection





Subject Caps Percentage – proportion of capital letters in the subject

Body Caps Percentage – proportion of capital letters in the email body

Suspicious Keyword Count – number of phishing-related words

URL Label – whether the URL is suspicious

Composite Score – weighted combination of multiple features






A bar chart makes it easy to compare numerical values across features

Ordering from most to least important highlights key factors

Helps communicate insights to both technical and non-technical audiences





Visualization clarifies which features are most predictive

Focusing on key metrics makes insights actionable

Clear visualizations improve communication of findings

title: Home
text:
I am Brian Liew, a student at SIT with a passion for data analysis, visualization, and machine learning.
I built this portfolio to: - Showcase my projects
- Highlight my technical skills
- Demonstrate my ability to turn data into actionable insights



The portfolio is meant to: - Share my learning journey
- Explain the thought process behind my projects
- Show how I communicate technical findings clearly



The portfolio contains: - Home page – Introduction and overview
- Data Visualization – Key visualizations and feature analysis
- Reflection – Lessons learned and critical thinking
- Final Year Project (FYP) – End-to-end machine learning project
